statements.name: PROC TRANSPOSE
statements.description: Creates an output data set by restructuring the values in a SAS data set, transposing selected variables into observations.
statements.help:
PROC TRANSPOSE 
            <DATA=input-data-set>
            <DELIMITER=delimiter>
            
            <LABEL=label>
            
	<LET>
            <NAME=name>
            <OUT=output-data-set>
            <PREFIX=prefix>
            <SUFFIX=suffix>;                   
	ATTRIB  variable-list(s) 
               attribute-list(s);
            
	BY 
               <DESCENDING>
               variable-1
               
		
               <<DESCENDING>variable-2  ...>
		
               <NOTSORTED>;
            
	COPY 
               variable(s);
            
	FORMAT 
               variable-1
               < ...variable-n>
               <format>
               <DEFAULT=default-format>;
            
	ID 
               variable;
            
	
               
		IDLABEL 
                  variable; 
            
            
	LABEL 
               variable-1=label-1< ...variable-n=label-n>;
            
	VAR 
               variable(s); 
            
	WHERE 
               where-expression-1
		
               <logical-operator where-expression-n>;

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: names the SAS data set to transpose.

arguments.name: DELIMITER=
arguments.description: specifies a delimiter to use in constructing names for transposed variables in the output data set. If specified, the delimiter is inserted between variable values if more than one variable has been specified in the ID statement.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a name for the variable in the output data set that contains the label of the variable that is being transposed to create the current observation.

arguments.name: LET
arguments.description: allows duplicate values of an ID variable. PROC TRANSPOSE transposes the observation that contains the last occurrence of a particular ID value within the data set or BY group.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name for the variable in the output data set that contains the name of the variable that is being transposed to create the current observation.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: names the output data set. If output-data-set does not exist, then PROC TRANSPOSE creates it by using the DATAn naming convention.

arguments.name: PREFIX=
arguments.description: specifies a prefix to use in constructing names for transposed variables in the output data set. For example, if PREFIX=VAR, then the names of the variables are VAR1, VAR2, …,VARn.

arguments.name: SUFFIX=
arguments.description: specifies a suffix to use in constructing names for transposed variables in the output data set.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Orders the output according to the BY groups.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then either the observations in the data set must be sorted by all the variables that you specify, or they must be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way (for example, chronological order).

statements.name: COPY
statements.description: Copies variables directly from the input data set to the output data set without transposing them.

arguments.name: variable(s)
arguments.description: names one or more variables that the COPY statement copies directly from the input data set to the output data set without transposing them.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: Specifies one or more variables in the input data set whose nonmissing formatted values name the transposed variables in the output data set. When a variable name is being formed in the transposed (output) data set, the formatted values of all listed ID variables are concatenated in the same order that the variables are listed in the ID statement. The PREFIX=, DELIMITER=, and SUFFIX= options can be used to modify the formed variable name. The PREFIX= option specifies a common character or character string to appear at the beginning of the formed variable names. The DELIMITER= option specifies a common character or character string to be inserted between the values of the ID variables. The SUFFIX= option specifies a common character or character string to be appended to the end of each formed variable name.

arguments.name: variable(s)
arguments.description: names one or more variables whose formatted values are used to form the names of the variables in the output data set.

statements.name: IDLABEL
statements.description: Creates labels for the transposed variables.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names the variable whose values the procedure uses to label the variables that the ID statement names. variable can be character or numeric.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

arguments.name: variable(s)
arguments.description: names one or more variables to transpose.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
